item.title: Blog Post - First Real Post!
item.description: First blog post, sharing some art about a little about me.
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h1>
 First Real Post!
</h1>
<h2>
 First real post
</h2>
<p>
 How exciting! (lol)
</p>
<p>
 No art to really post about, I did practice today but didn't get anything of note. It's been like... 4 months since I last picked up my art stuff... so very rusty!
</p>
<p>
 But I bought an art tablet today! Yay! But why buy it? Well my art supplies are kinda old, especially the erasers. They love to leave smudges and it's quite annoying. But more so than that, productions will be a lot faster this way, using references on the computer vs eyeing on paper will save lots of time. Overall this is a great way to speed things up.
</p>
<p>
 Another reason why is my process is kinda slow. I would first draw on paper, take a pic, then draw that on the computer. Why start on paper? I only had a mouse and while I have done a few art stuff with only the mouse as seen below:
</p>
<img alt="Picture of Pretz" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/pretz.png"/>
<p>
 This character is named Pretz, made in 2018. Not much to say.
</p>
<img alt="Banner for Oceanfront 4" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/oceanfront 4.png"/>
<p>
 This is the banner I made for a friend for Oceanfront 4. Great tourney.
</p>
<img alt="Banner for Oceanfront 5" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/oceanfront 5.png"/>
<p>
 This is the banner I made for my friend yet again, for Oceanfront 5. So many great memories! The logo was made by my good friend, Tercero.
</p>
<p>
 For those curious, I got the Wacom Intuos Small Graphics Drawing Tablet. Medium costs too much and a good friend of mine recommended me this; she uses it personally and makes amazing art. I commissioned her to make this—based on my OSRS character (I don't own Justicar anymore though lol). Check her out
 <a href="https://twitter.com/NsNapk1" target="_blank">
  here
 </a>
 .
</p>
<img alt="OSRS character with Justicar armor" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/runescape_guy.png"/>
<p>
 That's all that there is to write about for now. I'll be receiving it tomorrow (9/28) and will be practicing. Next update should be more exciting.
</p>
]]>

item.title: First real drawing with the tablet
item.description: First art with tablet and favicon.
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h2>
 Website changes
</h2>
<p>
 Some things you may have noticed is I added a favicon, should hopefully work on all systems. Also new logo! I know it's not anything special, but it works for now which is all thats really required. Secondly I forgot to show the twitter for the person I commissioned to, so if you like the art, check her out! Link will also be here.
 <a href="https://x.com/ez_syrup_" target="_blank">
  https://x.com/ez_syrup_
 </a>
</p>
<p>
 Here is the quick sketch I made for the logo.
</p>
<img alt="my logo as a now" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/llogoreal.png"/>
<h2>
 Talking about my tablet
</h2>
<p>
 Still trying to get used to a few things. One, actually using it. I like the feeling of the tablet, it has a texture similar to paper, but it's a bit more rough, like 300 grit or so. The drivers also work under Linux just fine! But when its unplugged or if my pc turns off (which is every night) I have to set up the scripts again. No sudo needed :3
</p>
<pre><code class="bash">
xsetwacom set 8 MapToOutput 1920x1080+1920+0
xsetwacom set 8 Area 0 0 15200 8550
            </code></pre>
<p>
 But outside of that it just works out of the box. I'm using Krita, after doing some research it seems to just be the best option for native Linux usage. It's certainly a lot different than what I used to use when I was on Windows, so I've been adjusting to it for a bit.
</p>
<p>
 I didn't have much time to make something today cause I tried to figure out why the favicon wasn't working. So I only really made a simple quick sketch. The pressure-sensitive pen feels a lot better than a mouse, though I may have to mess with the settings a bit. Still getting used to it all.
</p>
<p>
 This was made in like 7 minutes, so it's a bit rough, especially the neck (lol)
</p>
<img alt="first sketch with tablet" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/random_girl.png"/>
<p>
 Anyways, I'll be working on an actual picture throughout the week, hopefully by the end of the week it'll be done. Maybe I'll have a post before with random stuff. See you next time!
</p>
]]>

item.title: Blog Post - Second Picture
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h1>
 Second Picture
</h1>
<h2>
 Learnt Lessons
</h2>
<p>
 Welcome back! Been working to push through to finish this on time. It ended up being more complicated than I thought it was going to be at first. 
                Coloring sure is hard. Actually, I broke the tip of the pen from how hard I was pressing, whoops! Thankfully the pen comes with more, 
                if I start to damage it more but I'll be more careful next time! Here's how it looks lol.
</p>
<img alt="Broken pen nib" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/pen down.png"/>
<img alt="Broken pen nib" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/pen_down2.png"/>
<p>
 I'll mess with pressure sensitivity within Krita to hopefully not repeat this again! But enough about me, what about the picture? 
                I finished this afternoon (10/14) but had to go into work so I couldn't actually finish making this entry.
</p>
<h2>
 What You Came to See
</h2>
<img alt="PSO Gifoie" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/gifoie done.png"/>
<p>
 I know the fire is less than desirable, but I didn't have much time left and I want to stick to my schedule! 
                Outside of that, I think the coloring turned out decent for the most part. Adding water colors on top of each other makes it darker 
                than I thought, so I had to work around that. But I really like water coloring in Krita, makes shading pretty easy vs flat colors.
</p>
<p>
 The left hand probably could have been fixed a bit more, but oh well. The art is based on my Phantasy Star Online character 
                casting Gifoie, which is an aoe fire spell that spins around the user in a circle. I based the art on the card of the same name from Episode 3.
</p>
<h2>
 What's Next?
</h2>
<p>
 I'll continue to use water coloring in my pictures going forward I think, I like the effect a lot, very nostalgic in a way. 
                As for what's next, I'm gonna work on a smaller project. My wrist has been hurting a bit, haven't taken care of my hands during this drawing process - and it shows.
</p>
<p>
 I'll be making Twitch emotes for my channel, as I got affiliate a while ago, but I still only have the default emotes! 
                It's a smaller size project - I know, but I think that it's gonna be good while I focus on my wrist. That's all there is for me tonight! See you guys next week.
</p>
]]>

item.title: Blog Post - New Emotes
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h1>
 New Emotes
</h1>
<h2>
 Didn't Think You'd See Me So Soon?
</h2>
<p>
 I finished my emotes (which are now live on Twitch!) in a pretty short time. Take a look!
</p>
<img alt="First emote is of Josette, being my ayayaya" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/josette wip.png"/>
<img alt="Second emote is of Yumimi giving a heart" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/yumimi.png"/>
<img alt="Third emote is of a character from OSRS" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/nezzy.png"/>
<img alt="Fourth emote is of my FF11 character being angry" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/angry mithra real.png"/>
<img alt="Last emote is of Link crying" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/sad link.png"/>
<p>
 Why flat colors? Twitch emotes' biggest file size is 112x112. For comparison, the Atari 2600 has a resolution of 160x192, 
                and the NES has 256x240. There's very little room to make things in, so I think flat colors help make things pop out a lot more. 
                Also, I tried to not have things that were related to me or the stream, instead of trying to make it more "generic" like a persona.
</p>
<p>
 I'll be making one more picture before my vacation starting on Nov 9, so I'll be giving myself more than a week. 
                After I come back on Nov 11, I'll be starting up once again.
</p>
<p>
 That's all from me today!
</p>
]]>

item.title: Blog Post - First Picture
item.description: Talking about myself and some of my art.
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h1>
 First Picture
</h1>
<h2>
 Get Ready!
</h2>
<p>
 Good morning! It's @705 swatch beats! After spending an hour on the art to clean it up, I'll be releasing it today! 
                It's a bit scary releasing art so publicly, but overall I think it turned out well enough. 
                If I had more time, I'd keep working on it, but I'm trying to train myself to get artwork done by the week.
</p>
<p>
 I don't want to be that student where the teacher goes, "Put your pencils down, time's done," 
                and I'm still writing, going, "Yeah, it's going down, just one more second!"
</p>
<h2>
 What You Came to See
</h2>
<p>
 But who is the character? No technical name, but they're called Radiant (lol) from the hit game, Final Fantasy XI. 
                They're a Mithra (cat girl) and a Paladin wearing an Adaman Cuirass Set, though the boots are the Gallant Breeches 
                because stats-wise, it's a lot better. I tried to make something a bit dynamic, with her moving around. 
                I think it turned out well enough.
</p>
<img alt="Picture of Mithra from Final Fantasy XI as a Paladin in Adaman Cuirass" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/complete picture.png"/>
<p>
 Tell me what you think! Next picture will hopefully be done by next week. It'll be in colo(u)r, but the main picture will more than likely 
                be pretty simple. Gotta practice one step at a time.
</p>
]]>

item.title: Blog Post - It's Been a While, Oops
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h1>
 It's Been a While, Oops
</h1>
<h2>
 Where Have You Been?
</h2>
<p>
 I didn't mean to leave this dormant for as long as I did, that shouldn't happen again. 
                I thought I'd get the picture done before the vacation happened - clearly it didn't happen. 
                But I should have at least posted an interesting story or something.
</p>
<h2>
 Speaking of Something Interesting
</h2>
<p>
 I came back from Battle at the Border, a Smash 64 tourney in Arizona. I won't discuss much in this post 
                as I want to create a whole dedicated post to it, to partner with a vlog that I have planned. 
                Lots of pictures were taken during the traveling, and I'm excited to talk about them. 
                This was the first event I went to out of state for, basically one part of the states to another. 
                But I loved my time. That's not to say that I didn't do any drawing before the event.
</p>
<h2>
 What Is This Man Cooking
</h2>
<p>
 I made an emote for a friend, which is actually a remake of an older one. 
                The old one was probably one of my least favorite ones, so I was happy when he wanted me to work on it again! 
                Overall, I'm happy with how this turned out. Sure, it's another shorter one, but a picture is a picture /s.
</p>
<img alt="Emote for my friend, arhkma_muddykipz" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/ciel emote.png"/>
<p>
 It's of the character Ciel from Tsukihime/Melty Blood eating a fried curry, something she's fond of. 
                There are plans for more drawings, but I want to work on the vlog, which may take a while. Unsure yet... it is art, 
                just in a different format. Until next time!
</p>
]]>

item.title: Blog Post - Quick Art I Made
item.description: Fritz the cat art and Oceanfront talk.
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h1>
 Quick Art I Made
</h1>
<h2>
 Hey There, I Didn't Forget About You Guys
</h2>
<p>
 During December I'm going to be busy making art for my good friend Arhkma for his tourney, 
                Oceanfront 6! I've been making art for him for the past few tourneys, and the tourney (which I hope 
                to be entering) will be on January 14. Some assets have to be made to help with his advertisement, 
                along with a few other artists (that are better than me).
</p>
<h2>
 What Have I Been Cooking?
</h2>
<p>
 I made this art from the movie 'Fritz the Cat':
</p>
<img alt="Fritz the Cat hiding after he started a revolt" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/fritz.png"/>
<p>
 One of my favorite scenes from the movie, and it was fun to work on. I may be able to get another - 
                non-Oceanfront - picture made, but I'm uncertain yet. Outside of that, the translation project 
                has been going well. The new tool has been absolutely amazing for speed, and I finished the good route 
                (though not tested yet), but I expect it to all be done soon.
</p>
<p>
 That's all from me today.
</p>
]]>

item.title: Blog Post - Random Stuff
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h1>
 Random Stuff
</h1>
<h2>
 What's the Scoop?
</h2>
<p>
 My friend Arhkma has commissioned me to work on a logo for an up-and-coming series he's planning 
                on doing - no spoilers just yet - but I have less than a week to complete the whole project. How 
                scary, but I think I can get it done. I've made some art before that happened, so let's drop that:
</p>
<img alt="Based on ALttP Dark Work art" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/dark work.png"/>
<p>
 This was meant to be a bigger-scale project; however, the call to action happened, and I didn't 
                have time to work on it further. Though this is still something I may return back to.
</p>
<img alt="Art for a sick friend" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/for lily.png"/>
<p>
 I have a friend who has recently been hospitalized. I don't want to share the info as it's personal 
                data, but I drew this for them, and while I wouldn't call this close to my best work, being able to 
                finish it in about 2 hours without prep - I think it turned out great.
</p>
<h2>
 So What Now?
</h2>
<p>
 As I said, I'll be working hard on that logo for Arhkma, and when that's finished, I'll be releasing 
                it here as well. I should be able to work on a bigger project after and maybe take a break for 
                Christmas - I'll certainly be busy with work.
</p>
<p>
 That's all from me.
</p>
]]>

item.title: Blog Post - Finished the Art
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h1>
 Finished the Art
</h1>
<h2>
 What's Good?
</h2>
<p>
 Hey, I know it’s been nearly a month. I didn’t think it’d take as long as it did to finish the art - 
                work has been really kicking my ass. Also, some news: the Melting Core episode was released! You can 
                see it here:
 <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SZZH4aTO9rQ" target="_blank">
  Watch on YouTube
 </a>
 . 
                You can even see me in the credits :3.
</p>
<p>
 As I said, work has been completely pwning me. I finished the background in like two to three days, 
                but then work kept pulling me in, only allowing me to work on it for an hour or so a day, really 
                slowing things down - as you can clearly see. But we got it done in the end. This art is for a poster 
                that will be raffled off. Hopefully, more are made to be sold at the event, but that’s not up to me. 
                Sadly, I won’t be attending the event as the announcement was done a bit late, and there’s not enough 
                time to request off, but I do plan to go to the one in summer and back to Arizona for BatB 2.
</p>
<h2>
 Yeah Yeah, What About the Art? Show Us.
</h2>
<p>
 It’s coming, don’t worry. Overall, I think it turned out pretty well, and I’m fairly happy with it. 
                I think Link’s legs could have been more spread out, but I quite liked the outcome as is. Take a look:
</p>
<img alt="Poster for Oceanfront 6" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/of6.png"/>
<p>
 I write this as I listen to some Ogre Battle 64 OST. The official CD release has the uncompressed 
                versions of the music for all the tracks, and it sounds quite lovely, even if I think the game has 
                issues overall. I’ll be taking the rest of the year off and will resume art next year. Until next time!
</p>
<h2>
 Update
</h2>
<p>
 Having issues with Jekyll pushing this to live. Trying to get it fixed now. This was originally made 
                on 12/25.
</p>
]]>

item.title: New Art Drop
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h1>
 Back so soon?
</h1>
<p>
 Indeed, didn't have to keep you waiting for so long this time.
</p>
<h2>
 Progress on translation project?
</h2>
<p>
 Currently I'm waiting for my friend to proofread my work, the last translators stopped their work on chapter 5, with barely any work done on chapter 6. Once he finishes that, we'll make a proper xdelta patch. But for now it's mostly a waiting game.
</p>
<h2>
 New art?
</h2>
<p>
 Indeed, I've been cooking up some new art, and eventually will be my pfp until something else comes up that I like.
</p>
<img alt="Picture of my pso character, a Fomarl with Chao Striker" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/chao.png"/>
<p>
 The thing I really wanted to focus on was proportions, though she's technically shorter than what's shown in this picture, tall girls can be cute too, lol.
</p>
<p>
 One thing I really thought about was about what is good art vs bad art; and ultimately I came to the conclusion that it didn't matter in the end. What's good vs bad only really matters in the context of business, but what's really important is how much effort you put in, and the more you try at it, the more you end up liking it, regardless of its "quality".
</p>
<p>
 Comparing how the art looks compared to other people's art is fruitless as you can try to copy someone's art style but you'll never be satisfied compared to making something on your own, and putting in your own effort.
</p>
<p>
 Basically what I'm saying is that I'm happy with how it turned out, and that's more important than me trying to make "good" art compared to other people. I also tried to make a new pfp as my current one is still the Link one I made for Christmas, but I didn't like how it turned out, but here's how it looks.
</p>
<img alt="OSRS character wearing Nezzy help with face guard" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/unused.png"/>
<p>
 It was just a bit too big for my liking, like too close to the camera, even though I think it turned out okay.
</p>
<p>
 That's all from me today.
</p>
]]>

item.title: Lupin III translation released
item.description: Vacation pics and translation project cliff notes.
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h1>
 Sorry for those waiting for the art tutorial, but it's still coming!
</h1>
<p>
 I've been on vacation the past week with my good friend Arhkma, which has been an absolute treat. Here are a few pictures of my time there, and some relaxing music accompanies them. We went to Anna Marie Island for a few days, which was amazing! The scenery was beautiful, and the food was overall great. The place was hotter than I'm used to, but we got through it all. The house was kinda awkward, as there were a lot of stairs to climb, with separate small homes to the main one. The alarm system sucked as well, it was always enabled, and you had to press a "Bypass" button to not sound the alarm. The alarm didn't call the cops or anything; it was just a loud buzzer and really annoying.
</p>
<p>
 The street situation was weird since many homes were built on the main roads, which made traffic kinda a pain to go through, along with, generally speaking, having smaller roads, making things a lot tighter to get around.
</p>
<p>
 I'm very thankful for Arhkma for inviting me, it was the first vacation I've had since Battle at the Border in Az, and it was just so much fun, and words can not describe how thankful I've been for being invited. We got a few recording sessions, finished "River City Girls," and started the second game. It was a very fun beat 'em up, great music, and fun gameplay, even if it was a bit stiff with combos, and exploring felt boring after getting close to the game. Keep an eye out on
 <a href="https://www.youtube.com/@arhkma_muddykipz" target="_blank">
  Arhkma's YouTube for this release, along with many more to come with us!
 </a>
</p>
<audio controls="">
 <source src="../../audio/Indio.flac" type="audio/flac"/>
</audio>
<img alt="Sun rise by bed" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/vacataion 1.jpg"/>
<img alt="Funny bottle" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/vacation 10.jpg"/>
<img alt="Ramen Noodles" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/vacataion 2.jpg"/>
<img alt="Flower" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/vacataion 3.jpg"/>
<img alt="Breakfast" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/vacataion 4.jpg"/>
<img alt="Koi fish" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/vacataion 5.jpg"/>
<img alt="Sunset by beach" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/vacataion 6.jpg"/>
<img alt="Showing watch by sunset" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/vacataion 7.jpg"/>
<img alt="Shore line by sunset" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/vacataion 8.jpg"/>
<img alt="Sunset" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/vacataion 9.jpg"/>
<h2>
 Did you make a post to flex?
</h2>
<p>
 No! I actually have some great news as well. The other reason I haven't worked on my art tutorial yet is because I've been working on my project. Some people may remember me posting about it a while ago on the blog/hearing me talk about it, but after nearly 2 years (like a year and 3 months), the 1.0 is finally released!
</p>
<p>
 If you're interested, please check it out here:
 <a href="https://github.com/DOL-Translations/lupin-III" target="_blank">
  Lupin III Translation Project
 </a>
</p>
<h3>
 Some insight/timeline
</h3>
<audio controls="">
 <source src="../../audio/Whispers of the Gods.flac" type="audio/flac"/>
</audio>
<p>
 Since it's my blog, I've added some personal insight to the project overall. Lots of reading ahead.
</p>
<p>
 When the project started, the tools were absolutely awful. It could have taken an afternoon to even finish half a scene, and the lack of any compiler errors just made the whole process worse. When we got a handful of translators, they were going through the spreadsheet like it was nothing, but I could barely get halfway through chapter 1 after months - it was honestly miserable, and it felt bad.
</p>
<p>
 When NewGBAXL showed me PWtr's new tool, it was like a whole new world opened up. What would have taken me a few days could have been done in a few hours, and the amount of work/repetition required for the whole project was reduced immensely. I could catch up to where the translators were, which was chapter 5.
</p>
<p>
 A big issue surrounding the whole project was just getting translations done. I didn't want to rely just on DeepL/Google Translate, and I wanted the project to be fully translated by people with experience. However, most of the translators we could get were mostly college students, meaning their time was limited outside of summer. Jebbi could translate most of the game by herself, which was amazing. She said she had a lot of fun doing it. However, she moved to a new country, job, and life. So she was unable to continue translating past chapter 5.
</p>
<p>
 Cindi and Bingokemski could not stay on the project either, which left the project in a very awkward spot. Because of how effective the new tools were, I was able to catch up from chapter 1 to chapter 6 in about 2 weeks (!), but now with nobody to actually translate the project itself, there was very little to actually do.
</p>
<p>
 During this downtime, a person named aldi_09 joined up; they had an illustration degree and were very proficient with Photoshop. With their help, they were able to get the title screen re-done in English, along with the save banners, and around this time, NewGBAXL was able to insert new menu translation graphics.
</p>
<!-- Add additional content as needed -->
]]>

item.title: Post trip post.
item.description: Lara Croft art trade and foot notes for vlog.
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h1>
 I'm back.
</h1>
<audio controls="">
 <source src="../../audio/Payday.flac"/>
</audio>
<p>
 It's been a while, but I didn't forget about the blog; it's far from it! I didn't want to make a new post since I was waiting for Quilt to finish an art trade. But he was too busy, so instead of waiting, I figured I'd release some work I'd done.
</p>
<p>
 First, I went to Battle at the Border Dos earlier this month and made a vlog showcasing my experience! Check it out here
 <a href="https://youtu.be/HVJtQnYxiUg" target="_blank">
  Battle at the Border Dos Vlog
 </a>
</p>
<p>
 Secondly, I have done a few art projects since my last post, including my end of the art trade.
</p>
<p>
 Lastly, I finally added an RSS feed built into the blog, so feel free to add it.
</p>
<h2>
 My artwork
</h2>
<img alt="Lara Croft for Quilt" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/lara.png"/>
<p>
 I made this in about 5 days since I wanted to challenge myself and create something before my vacation. So, I could add more details since I came back from vacation. But for now, I'm considering it done as I finished it within my goal.
</p>
<p>
 But that doesn't mean I'm done posting! I've made a lot of art since my last post. For the private server Eden, they started to make a tribune for in-server stuff
 <a href="https://edenxi.miraheze.org/wiki/Eden_Tribune" target="_blank">
  Eden Tribune
 </a>
 . Though my art wasn't included, sadly, I still wanted to post it.
</p>
<img alt="Player fishing at Lufaise Meadows" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/fishing.png"/>
<p>
 Pretty cool! I tried to get some cooler colors to match the sunset. What was harder was coloring the mountains/grass instead of just the background, mixing the colors with the whole image. I quite liked how it turned out.
</p>
<img alt="Taru PUP talking to their automaton" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/taru.png"/>
<p>
 I didn't quite like how the other image I made for the tribune turned out, but since it was never included, I guess I'm fine with that. If I kept working on it, then I'd probably work on the perspective more.
</p>
<h2>
 My sketches
</h2>
<p>
 Those are the 3 main images that I worked on, but I'd done a handful of sketches during that time. I've been trying to get into a habit of making more sketches - even if I don't finish them. This is because I can finish them later when I have a more specific idea or if I have an idea but don't feel like working on it further.
</p>
<img alt="Girl holding something" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/girl holding.png"/>
<p>
 What could they be holding? I dunno.
</p>
<img alt="Mithra yelling" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/mithra angy.png"/>
<p>
 This is something I have a plan to finish; I just didn't have time to work on it.
</p>
<img alt="DRK and Mithra holding hands" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/elvaan mithra.png"/>
<p>
 This was meant to be a gift, but I decided to pivot into the fishing picture as I was having more fun with it instead. I'd probably finish it at some point or rework it for something later.
</p>
<img alt="Girl sitting down" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/sitting.png"/>
<p>
 I honestly forgot about this, but I was near finishing the sketching part; I mostly had to work on fixing up portions... I think this was like 4 months ago, lol.
</p>
<img alt="Gif for vlog video" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/disc gif.gif"/>
<p>
 I made this for the vlog, I cropped it later, but didn't save that one to the Linux OS, but here's how it was done. I actually made it with Wick Editor, which was the art program I used originally before I got my tablet.
</p>
<h2>
 Extra vlog tidbits.
</h2>
<audio controls="">
 <source src="../../audio/Sin Ella.flac"/>
</audio>
<p>
 If you aren't interested in the vlog, then you can stop reading here, but like with the Lupin post
 <a href="https://radiant-ink.com/posts/lupin-finshed/#so-whats-next" target="_blank">
  Lupin III Finished
 </a>
 , I added a few tidbits that I couldn't really post about elsewhere.
</p>
<p>
 Like 2 weeks before I went, my original plan/place I was staying ended up fizzing out, which made me pissed/scramble. The second option I had just didn't work out either, so I was worried if I would even get somewhere.
</p>
<p>
 Thankfully Closen was able to host me most days, so I was very thankful that he was able to come in clutch. If you compare the last one to this one, you'll notice that I haven't been able to hang out with my local friends for as long. I don't want to talk too much about it since it's personal and out of the scope of the vlog. But because of what was happening over there, I wasn't really allowed to stay over any.
</p>
<p>
 Closen told me that he was relatively recently diagnosed with Hypoglycemia, which is effectively the reverse of diabetes. This blood sugar level would drop too low, which made him feel dizzy/unwell. We talked about a few plans, but due to this, along with picking up people from the airport, we weren't always able to do them.
</p>
<p>
 For example, they had a new lion exhibit that was added to the local zoo that was talked about, but we never ended up going. Sadly, we also planned to go to the missions but never ended up doing that, either. Once, another place I wanted to go to was a Round 1 arcade, but it was nearly an hour-long drive, so I couldn't really go.
</p>
<p>
 It might seem weird for me to go to Arizona to go to a tourney, despite not even really wanting to play. I don't think I mentioned it in great detail, but I sold my controller a while ago. I was having some money problems, and because I felt pretty negatively about playing competitive Smash/not using the controller for anything but for Smash - I decided to just sell it for a pretty penny. It was a fully metal module, bowl, stick, and gears - so while I was a bit sad to sell it, as I had it for like 6 years, it was just better to give it to a new home.
</p>
<p>
 I really was just planning on vibing out and doing comms since I was more interested in doing that than playing. The only reason I even joined was because like 10 people dropped out a few days before the event, and I wanted to help out. The pools were so uneven that Closen was even thinking about two 4-man pools and two 7-man pools to try and even things out.
</p>
<p>
 I didn't have any fun playing the games, so I ended up just walking around after not doing well in pools. I wanted to walk around to sorta clear out my head and not be a grouch around other people and ruin their time.
</p>
<p>
 In the video, I talked about having $10 in cash. When I was at the end game bar, they had a Beatmania complete Mix 2, which I was pretty excited about playing, so I took out $20 from the atm, converted $10 of it into coins, and then kept about $10 for myself. But when I went to play it, it was turned off. I asked the front desk girl about it; she said she'd turn it on. but then it turns out that it was out of service. I was pissed, lol. After going to the Electric Bat arcade, I used the first $10 but then had to go to a gas station to exchange the $10 in quarters into dollars so as not to walk around with a plastic cup full of change.
</p>
<p>
 I really like my time at Electric Bat. Barely anybody was even at the rhythm game section, which meant I didn't have to pass up turns with other players, but the area around it is pretty sketchy. A few times, I went outside for a break, but then I'd see some cars parked far away at a closed-down place, and I walked right back into the bar, lol.
</p>
<p>
 I was sad that I had completely forgotten about the cat bar, and I wish I had gone. When I found out, I was just leaving the mall, going to the electric bat arcade, trying to go asap, because it was around 3 PM, and Uber/Waymo, we were gonna start to get pricer.
</p>
<p>
 When I came back from walking around outside after losing in pools, I was talking to Spo, asking him if he was hungry. He said he had already eaten, but I asked him where he had gone. He ate at the venue, which surprised me because I thought the food last time was honestly pretty mid af, which is like most bar food. But he was so drunk that "The food just goes down."
</p>
<p>
 I thought about going to the upstairs venue to see the club, and I was actually considering going, but I didn't feel like spending $10 to mostly walk around for a few minutes and then leave. However, part of me wishes I had gone because it would have been an experience, even if I hadn't strictly enjoyed it.
</p>
<p>
 The Waymo was super cool; it was a somewhat slow but very comfy car ride, safer than some Uber drivers I've had in the past. Despite it being a little scary the first few minutes, I ended up just forgetting I was in a self-driving car and just vibed out.
</p>
<p>
 That's all from me today. expect a part 2 to art tutorials, as I enjoyed making the first one a lot.
</p>
]]>

item.title: I've been "busy".
item.description: Translation project update and MMR Speedrun announcement.
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h1>
 I'm a terrible host
</h1>
<p>
 Clearly it's been busy with work a bit, and I was working on my translation project for a while. The good news is that I was able to get disc 2, which is an FMV of animation. Originally there wasn't a way to get English text with the in-game engine, but I found a way to insert my own video with subtitles spliced inside of them. Another thing I was working on was playing more Glover.
</p>
<p>
 The Misfit Mascot Replay is a speedrunning event where people play games for old/dead mascots. I originally wasn't going to even play, and I just signed up for commentary, but one of the rules for the event is you need 4 players to play (there are 4 different groups), and there was about a week before they closed submissions. Wanting the game to get into the event, I joined. I haven't played in about a year, so I have to practice a bunch just to get consistent again, which obviously takes time to get rid of the rust. Here's the trailer
 <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NodLpx5NrEQ" target="_blank">
  watch the trailer
 </a>
 .
</p>
<p>
 On better news, I got a new keyboard!
 <a href="https://varmilo.com/products/minilo75?variant=44272593862875" target="_blank">
  Check it out here
 </a>
 . I'm still getting a bit used to the feeling of a smaller keyboard, but the super quiet keycaps are amazing. It doesn't require as much force to type, so sometimes I press down on a key after I finish typing, which is... cool. It also came with a Bluetooth dongle, which works for the Wii, and thus works for Phantasy Star Online!
</p>
<img alt="Phantasy Star Online in-game keyboard working" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/pso.jpg"/>
<p>
 The translation is 2 chapters away from finishing, along with someone with proper Japanese skills to translate disc 2 properly. I used YouTube's auto-translate, along with basic speaking skills to make it, but for now, work is slowing way down, and my translation project is on hold for now as well.
</p>
<p>
 The other thing I've been doing is playing Like a Dragon: Infinite Wealth, super amazing game and I'm definitely addicted to it, lol. I'm 58 hours in and I still haven't beaten the game yet, but I think I'm close.
</p>
<h2>
 So what are the plans going forward?
</h2>
<p>
 I have already made two sketches that need to be finished, and I have some more ideas as well, so I'm certainly not short on things to make. Outside of that, I'll want to finish the game itself. The translation will mostly be on pause until someone is able to help finish translating the last 2 chapters, though thankfully we're almost done! If you're interested in the page, check it out here
 <a href="https://github.com/DOL-Translations/lupin-III" target="_blank">
  Lupin III translation
 </a>
 .
</p>
<p>
 On March 16, around 10:20 pm EST, I'll be playing Glover live for the relay, so I'll be practicing again for a bit.
</p>
<p>
 I promise the next post will be an art-related one, and won't take another month to do, lol.
</p>
]]>

item.title: Dropping the latest album
item.description: FOmarl with Soul Eater in Ruins 3
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h1>
 Whoever said they can't be happy never purchased a box full of popsicles with jokes on them.
</h1>
<p>
 I don't have too much to say this time actually. My translation project has been on halt for a while, as I still can't find someone to help finish translating chapter 6 and 8. However, I was able to encode a new THP (GameCube video format) to replace disc 2's FMV. So I was able to put subs in the video! Someone I found on GitHub helped me fix some issues with the audio being slowed down! There's still some slight audio pops, but hopefully, that'll be fixed soon!
</p>
<p>
 Also, since my last post, I did get into MMR, and was only 2 minutes off my PB, so that's not too bad! I put Glover in for the next MMR, so maybe I'll be able to play again. I didn't practice as much as I wanted to last time as work has been owning me.
</p>
<h2>
 What about LaD?
</h2>
<p>
 I did actually beat that! 76.8 hours in total. The first part had too many cutscenes and was a bit boring. The middle portion was absolutely amazing, and I loved all the gameplay changes as well. But the ending didn't feel complete, and I was forced to grind twice in a row, which was disappointing to me. NG+ is locked behind $15 of DLC, so :/. I think I like the first game more, it felt more complete, even if it's worse in a lot of different ways.
</p>
<h2>
 Bro keeps yapping, what about the picture?
</h2>
<p>
 Yea, yea. I'm getting to that point. The line drawing was made a while ago, but despite being a slower season for work, I've been quite busy – there's some reasons for this, but it's not important. I think FINALLY I'm getting back to having a bit more time to do other stuff, lol. I did try to add in a bit more shading to this picture, but also I'm very late, so I didn't spend as much time as I originally wanted to.
</p>
<img alt="FOmarl in Ruins" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/soul_background.png"/>
<p>
 I tried to add a background to the image, but Paint.net transparency seemed to not enjoy working with this art, and the background was added last minute. It wasn't made with it in mind. I got the background image from here
 <a href="https://imgur.com/user/Nostalgio" target="_blank">
  here
 </a>
 .
</p>
<img alt="FOmarl casting lightning 2" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/soul.png"/>
<p>
 There's the image without the background, also featuring the weapon called "Soul Eater".
</p>
<p>
 I still have 1 other rough sketch complete, and a few more ideas I wanna get to. It won't be that long till the next time, surely. Clueless.
</p>
]]>

item.title: Imagine Radiant posting a weekly post, can't be me.
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h1>
 What a rare sight!
</h1>
<p>
 I made some new art to share, along with some ideas on how to get more art out there. Not sure how well it'll actually go. Instead of forcing a once per week (lol) art that's also colored, I could instead work on some sketches, and if I like the art enough to color it, then I'll do it. This way I get more art practice without trying to force it out.
</p>
<p>
 I also met a nice pal from PSO named bflo who I should be making an art trade with soon. He's a lot better than I am at art, but check him out here:
 <a href="https://nezerelli.wixsite.com/bflo" target="_blank">
  https://nezerelli.wixsite.com/bflo
 </a>
 and he indirectly gave me an idea for something I can add to spice up some posts! I'll be including a song (doesn't have to be related to the art itself) to go along with the posts.
</p>
<p>
 Of course, volume warning:
</p>
<audio controls="">
 <source src="../..//audio/The Epic Remains.flac" type="audio/flac"/>
</audio>
<p>
 It's fairly easy to include, and all my song files are tagged, so it's easy to figure out where they're from.
</p>
<h2>
 What about the art?
</h2>
<p>
 Yea, yea, I'm getting to that. I've recently been playing some Ragnarok Online on the server Payon, so I made the art for my character along with them wearing a Dragonfire Shield from OSRS (which I'm surprised I haven't really made any art for).
</p>
<img alt="Swordsman with a spear" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/ro.png"/>
<p>
 And I made another sketch, I didn't really like how it turned out, which is what made me want to try out the idea as posted above.
</p>
<img alt="Kuru from Rhapsody: A Musical Adventure" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/kuru.png"/>
<p>
 However, this means I'm legally obligated to post another song from the game, because it's quite good.
</p>
<audio controls="">
 <source src="../../audio/Evil Queen.flac" type="audio/flac"/>
</audio>
]]>

item.title: New Website
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h1>
 Hello, and welcome to the new blog!
</h1>
<p>
 I'm sure as you guys can see, I completely changed the layout of my blog. This was something I'd been thinking about for a while.
</p>
<h1>
 But why?
</h1>
<p>
 This was a layout I always wanted but decided that I didn't want to do it at the time, and instead, I went for Jekyll. But I wanted to make things more personal, and include things that I couldn't before. So now, here we are.
</p>
<h1>
 What about the old layout?
</h1>
<p>
 Its currently archived right now, just hidden. If I decide that the current iteration is too much to handle, then I can always fall back on it. Otherwise, this will be the new base of operation, and the old layout isn't going to be used for now.
</p>
<audio controls="">
 <source src="../../audio/popn.flac"/>
</audio>
<p>
 I now have a section with all my old artwork, (mostly) organized neatly by year and date made, a completely different section for the tutorial series, to make it easier to follow.
</p>
<p>
 While this takes more work for me to run, I think it's overall not too bad.
</p>
<h1>
 Did you make any new art?
</h1>
<p>
 Sorta? Because I spent so much time the past month working on the new layout, and the next part of the tutorial is done, I didn't really have time to many any art for the new year. But that's okay, it's just another year.
</p>
<p>
 But outside of the new tutorial section I made, I also made a completely new banner! I spent a fair amount of time working on it, and I'm planning on working on my coloring more this year. But here it is, without the text.
</p>
<img alt="New banner" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/blog/banner.png"/>
<p>
 I quite liked how it turned out! At any rate, your bookmarking/rss should be the same, so no need to update it. But if you haven't, please subscribe to my RSS to get the latest updates on my work!
</p>
<p>
 That's all from me today, I hope you guys had a good holiday/new years, and I'll see you guys next time.
</p>
]]>

item.title: Art Tutorial 1 - Radiant Ink
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h1>
 Art Tutorial 1
</h1>
<audio controls="">
 <source src="../audio/Technology.flac"/>
</audio>
<h2>
 The things you'll need:
</h2>
<p>
 A pencil with an eraser, a pen, paper (preferably not lined). Ideally a sketchbook, printer paper will also work. A ruler, a compass (or anything small that can make perfect circles, bottle caps, cups), and lastly a good attitude for learning, since we're all bad when we start.
</p>
<h2>
 So you have everything gathered, now what?
</h2>
<p>
 First we have to figure out how to hold the pencil before we can even start! You can hold it 2 ways: as close to the base as you can, or as close to touching the eraser. How you hold it will depend on what's currently being drawn.
</p>
<p>
 Another thing to note is that you should NEVER draw dark; you have to draw light so it's easy to erase and draw again. Once things look nice, then you're gonna use a pen.
</p>
<p>
 I repeat, under no circumstances, do you draw dark with the pencil.
</p>
<h2>
 Now we can start drawing (for real)
</h2>
<p>
 We're gonna learn to draw a person, but we don't "just" draw. We have to learn what actually makes a human. No humans are the same, and when you're drawing something more cartoonic, the scale won't be the same. Even if you plan to draw more of an anime style, learning to draw correct proportions is important.
</p>
<h2>
 Learning to scale
</h2>
<p>
 In drawing, a body is measured in "heads," with the actual head at the top of the body. Different people will tell you different sizes, but I usually say 7 heads is a good size. Some people say 7.5, others 8. You'll also want to make the body 2 head sizes wide, if it's an even wider body, 2.5 is also good.
</p>
<p>
 As for how big you want the head to be, you want it to be a proper scale for your paper/how big you want it to be. (This is why we have a ruler!) So, if your paper is 8 inches tall, then 1 inch for a head size will give you a 7-inch tall human! This will be a bit tricky if you pose for more than straight on.
</p>
<p>
 Here are some pictures from different sources to help show off what I mean:
</p>
<img alt="Head size chart 1" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/body1.png"/>
<img alt="Head size chart 2" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/body2.jpg"/>
<img alt="Head size chart 3" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/body3.png"/>
<h2>
 So now we have scale, but how do we actually draw?
</h2>
<audio controls="">
 <source src="../audio/Serene Nights.flac"/>
</audio>
<p>
 An important thing to note is that everything we draw is actually just basic shapes—cones, rectangular prisms, cubes, and so on. For our example, the head will be a circle, and the arms and legs will be cylinders.
</p>
<p>
 Taking all that I said into consideration, here's what I've made to use as my example. You're welcome to use what I have drawn to follow the tutorial, but the tutorial should be detailed enough to follow with any pose. I do not recommend drawing a straight-on image, instead try drawing at an angle, even if slight. But that's up to you.
</p>
<img alt="Chart for body sizes" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/bodychart.png"/>
<p>
 It's hard to give a proper size on digital, but since I explained how to scale things already, you can use your own scale. Now let's start with drawing. I already have an idea for what I want, and if we follow the charts listed above, the simple shapes will come out perfectly.
</p>
<img alt="Body done" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/roughbody.png"/>
<audio controls="">
 <source src="../audio/Stolen Moments.flac"/>
</audio>
<h2>
 What are the extra things added?
</h2>
<p>
 For joint sizes, I try for 1/4 size of a head for both width and height. The girl is on her tippy toes, so the number of lines isn't the 7 I usually do, and we can say she's a bit taller than normal. Some people say 6 heads is good for girls' heights, and 7 for guys—but as I said, all body types aren't the same, so feel free to be creative.
</p>
<p>
 A simple way to measure feet is to use two ball joints, one for the joint itself and the other for the rest of the feet. I forgot to show this off.
</p>
<p>
 You'll also notice the head is below the line, which is on purpose for the pose I want to do. Each arm will be one head size (length), so even though it's bent, it's the correct size.
</p>
<p>
 Even if what you've done isn't very good, what you want to focus on is getting the correct proportion sizes over anything else. Everything else will fall into place. Lastly, this is just a rough draft, so don't worry if it's not perfect now.
</p>
<h2>
 Practice makes perfect
</h2>
<p>
 Don't just do this once and call it a day. You have to practice, do multiple poses, and focus on getting the exact sizes right. The size in my picture won't line up exactly with yours, but the method will still be the same.
</p>
<!-- Footer Section -->
<div class="footer">
 <a href="tuthome.html">
  Back to Tutorial Home
 </a>
 <a href="tut2.html">
  Next Tutorial
 </a>
</div>
]]>

item.title: Art Tutorial 2 - Radiant Ink
item.description: Learning to draw hands, head, feet.
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h1>
 Art Tutorial 2
</h1>
<p>
 <strong>
  Did you practice? I hope so.
 </strong>
</p>
<p>
 If you didn't practice, then it'll never work out (bitter smile). As long as you're able to get the correct sizing done, then you'll do well!
</p>
<p>
 This post will be a bit shorter, but we'll work on hands, feet, and the head, to create a complete figure to work on.
</p>
<h2>
 Lets start with the hand
</h2>
<audio controls="">
 <source src="../audio/Donpan Bushi.flac"/>
</audio>
<p>
 A lot of people say the hand is the hardest thing to draw, but that's mostly because they never learned how to do it proper! A hand is nothing more than a 3-D rectangle with some cylinders sticking out. Just make note that the hands are different where the left and the right are. Even I make this mistake sometimes.
</p>
<p>
 Start with a simple rectangular prism like such.
</p>
<img alt="Starting hand" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/handpart1.png"/>
<p>
 From there, you want to start adding the cylinders, attempting to make it both flushed together.
</p>
<img alt="Adding fingers to hand" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/handpart2.png"/>
<p>
 I shortened the rectangular prism a bit. Make note of the thumb placement, it has to be lower, and the tip close to the index finger. From there, we're gonna start shaving off portions of the simple shapes.
</p>
<img alt="Fixing up the hand" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/handpart3.png"/>
<p>
 And now we have a hand. Lets do another example.
</p>
<p>
 This one will be at a different angle. For general hand sizes, make 2 small balls, similar to joint sizes for the body. One ball for the hand, the other for the fingers.
</p>
<img alt="Starting another hand" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/handpart6.png"/>
<img alt="Complete" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/handpart4.png"/>
<img alt="Adding fingers" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/handpart5.png"/>
<h2>
 Now that we have knowledge on how to make hands, lets add some to our art.
</h2>
<audio controls="">
 <source src="../audio/April in Paris.flac"/>
</audio>
<p>
 Following what we just learned, I create the hands desired for my pose.
</p>
<img alt="Adding the hands to our picture" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/roughbody2.png"/>
<p>
 How about that? Just gotta keep practicing! Hands are usually the thing struggles with, along with faces (we'll go over them next). Just gotta practice!
</p>
<h2>
 Now on faces.
</h2>
<p>
 You can actually, calculate this with math and rulers, and if you really want to get in depth with this sort of thing, I can recommend some readings later.
</p>
<p>
 To make things simple, lets start with making a more correct head using a 2x3 square.
</p>
<img alt="Starting the head" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/headpart1.png"/>
<p>
 Next we will be drawing a circle in the first 2 squares, and we're gonna draw the chin (ignore how thick the circle is).
</p>
<img alt="Drawing the rest chin" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/headpart2.png"/>
<p>
 Now we're gonna do a bunch of math to fill in the rest. We're gonna measure the "eye" and use that to measure everything. We're gonna divide the squares into three equal parts.
</p>
<img alt="Dividing into three parts" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/headpart3.png"/>
<p>
 The lines aren't straight, but if you have ruler it'll be easier, but it should about like this. Next we're gonna add eyes, they'll be put at specific spots.
</p>
<img alt="Adding eyes" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/headpart4.png"/>
<p>
 Now for the lips, they're gonna be in the middle of the eye, above line 6.
</p>
<img alt="Adding Lips" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/facepart5.png"/>
<p>
 The ears will be added in the middle of the eye to about the nose bottom.
</p>
<img alt="Adding ears to the head" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/facdpart6.png"/>
<p>
 And now our face is complete! Its a bit creepy, isn't it? But once you add features, it'll be more appealing.
</p>
<p>
 If you want to understand this more, I recommend checking out this website. Ignore that it's old and in Japanese, and don't ask why I know of this old website. It's a very good/detailed guide.
</p>
<p>
 <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20030423135426/http://www1.dnet.gr.jp/~takayuki/syonen/art/frame.html" target="_blank">
  Link to the guide
 </a>
</p>
<h2>
 Now we'll add this to our body!
</h2>
<img alt="Adding facial features to body" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/roughbody3.png"/>
<h2>
 Now we'll finish with feet.
</h2>
<audio controls="">
 <source src="../audio/One Last Time.flac"/>
</audio>
<p>
 This part is pretty simple, as it's similar to hands, except the feet are a bit longer. Truthfully, I usually add shoes, boots, etc. So I never really practice proper feet much.
</p>
<p>
 We'll add a joint at the back of the feet, along with about the same size for the front. Since I normally put boots on, it'll look incomplete.
</p>
<img alt="Feet" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/roughfeet1.png"/>
<p>
 And now, we have our whole body set up! But its looking a bit blocky still. In the next lesson, we'll learn how to shape up the body.
</p>
<h2>
 You better practice!
</h2>
<div class="footer">
 <a href="tut1.html">
  Previous Tutorial
 </a>
 <a href="tuthome.html">
  Back to Tutorial Home
 </a>
 <a href="tut3.html">
  Next Tutorial
 </a>
</div>
]]>

item.title: Art Tutorial 3 - Radiant Ink
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h1>
 Art Tutorial 3
</h1>
<audio controls="">
 <source src="../audio/I'm Old Fasioned.flac"/>
</audio>
<h2>
 Welcome back!
</h2>
<p>
 This lesson will be short since we'll be finishing making our body. Different body shapes exist, depending on what you want to make. I'll show off a few pictures, and you'll decide what you want to make for your drawing.
</p>
<img alt="Body Female" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/femalebody.png"/>
<img alt="Second Body Female" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/body22.jpg"/>
<img alt="Male body" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/body3.jpg"/>
<img alt="Second Male Body" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/body4.jpg"/>
<p>
 Something to note is that you have to start the curve early at the top, and make sure the body ends by the hips properly. Similar to the face example, everything can be done with math, and you can line everything perfectly. I'll start with the main body for now.
</p>
<img alt="Adding a body" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/rough body 2.png"/>
<p>
 Because I'm drawing a female, I have to make sure to leave some room around the top/middle of the body for the breast, you can see the line is about where it'll end, leaving room for the stomach on the space below. Now we'll clean up our arms/legs.
</p>
<img alt="Body art done" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/rough body 4.png"/>
<p>
 It all started from basic shapes, and now we got our figure done! We're gonna work on clothes next time you're here, so be sure to have a full pose picture ready for that.
</p>
<!-- Footer Section -->
<div class="footer">
 <a href="tut2.html">
  Previous Tutorial
 </a>
 <a href="tuthome.html">
  Back to Tutorial Home
 </a>
 <a href="tut4.html">
  Next Tutorial
 </a>
</div>
]]>

item.title: Art Tutorial 4 - Radiant Ink
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h1>
 Art Tutorial 4
</h1>
<audio controls="">
 <source src="../audio/The Militia.flac"/>
</audio>
<h2>
 Welcome back
</h2>
<p>
 Hey there! I have some bigger projects in the pipeline, but I figured it'd be best to finish this tutorial first. We only have two lessons left anyway. Today, we'll be working on some clothes!
</p>
<p>
 There's a few things you have to understand first before we go into clothes, the most important thing is that cloth is some of the hardest thing to look amazing, so don't fret over if it's not as detailed as you'd like it to be, it just happens like that.
</p>
<p>
 You also want to determine what clothes you want for the drawing. While I can't go over every clothing style, I'll try to give a good overview. First, we'll start with shirts.
</p>
<p>
 The first thing to note is that you want to note is that the upper half of the body will typically be more "stuck" to the person compared to the bottom part. Now, this can depend on how the character pose is done, the state of the character, or finally, if you just want it to be a tight shirt for the booba. The best way to line things up is with the breast area being more of the middle portion (men have breasts, too).
</p>
<p>
 How far down you want it to be is also up to you. I tend to like the shirt over the pants, but that's also up to you. Dresses will be done similarly. Another nice thing is that you can mask bad body proportions if you mess things up. For now, the shirt will look flat in this instance, but once some detail is done, it'll look better.
</p>
<h2>
 Shirt Example
</h2>
<img alt="Example of a shirt" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/shirt.png"/>
<p>
 It'll look something like this. Using different colors/layers while drafting the image is always good. You'll want to use lighter colors if you're on paper/pencil.
</p>
<h2>
 Pants Example
</h2>
<img alt="Example of pants" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/pants.png"/>
<p>
 This looks rather simple, but it's just a sketch! Now, we'll add some more detail.
</p>
<audio controls="">
 <source src="../audio/Guitars, Whiskey, Guns And Knives.flac"/>
</audio>
<h2>
 Cleaning Up the Shirt and Pants
</h2>
<img alt="Cleaned up shirt and pants" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/shirt and pants.png"/>
<p>
 But now we'll add some detail to our clothing. A good way to add depth to a shirt is weight, showing one side having more of a "baggier area" than the other. We can also have parts of it fold onto itself, making it pop more.
</p>
<p>
 To add some detail to pants, you can add a design, maybe a belt, pockets, and some cuts. There are lots of options, depending on how you feel.
</p>
<h2>
 Final Shirt and Pants Example
</h2>
<img alt="New shirts and pants" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/shirt pants redone.png"/>
<p>
 Went from a fairly flat image to now something better.
</p>
<p>
 That's all the work done today! I'm pretty happy with it! The next lesson will be cleaning up the rest of the art, and adding a few more details.
</p>
<!-- Footer Section -->
<div class="footer">
 <a href="tut3.html">
  Previous Tutorial
 </a>
 <a href="tuthome.html">
  Back to Tutorial Home
 </a>
 <a href="tut5.html">
  Next Tutorial
 </a>
</div>
]]>

item.title: Art Tutorial 5 - Final | Radiant Ink
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h1>
 Art Tutorial 5, Final
</h1>
<audio controls="">
 <source src="../audio/El Conguero.flac"/>
</audio>
<h2>
 Hopefully your art has been great!
</h2>
<p>
 We'll be finishing up the art, cleaning it up, and making some fixes. This isn't a tutorial on coloring or shading, but I may do that in the future.
</p>
<p>
 So we need to make some hair and ears for our character still, and perhaps work on the eyes a bit more.
</p>
<p>
 If we use the analogy that a face is basically a mask, then the head is like a mannequin; if the hair is done right, it'll look natural and flow well. At this point, the measuring lines are no longer needed, so you can hide/remove them. If you do it with a pencil, you have to make sure you don't erase it too hard, or else it'll smudge the paper, and it won't look well.
</p>
<p>
 Hair is typically two eyes high above the eyes, with the eyelashes one above the eye. Hair will typically cover the whole top and backside of the head, but if you want it to be less, then you're more than welcome to it. Once again, start simple, don't try to overdraw the hair design, detail can go in later.
</p>
<p>
 A good way to clean up art is to actually redraw it, this will make things look more consistent, instead of trying to cut half of it, and drawing over it.
</p>
<p>
 After a few minutes, here we are! I quite like how it turned out. Just remember, practice makes perfect~!
</p>
<h2>
 Finished Art
</h2>
<img alt="Finished art" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/finshed tutorial.png"/>
<!-- Footer Section -->
<div class="footer">
 <a href="tut4.html">
  Previous Tutorial
 </a>
 <a href="tuthome.html">
  Back to Tutorial Home
 </a>
</div>
]]>

item.title: Art Tutorial 6 - Radiant Ink
item.ns0:encoded:
<![CDATA[<h1>
 Art Tutorial 6, learning to scale
</h1>
<audio controls="">
 <source src="../audio/Miracle Moon.flac"/>
</audio>
<h2>
 This will be a different type of tutorial
</h2>
<p>
 This won't be a proper drawing tutorial, and really, it's more of a way to force me to draw this stuff more often and, in doing so, get more ideas for other stuff I want to do. But it should give a few ideas. Keep in mind ALL pictures drawn are drawn in 1000x1000, I like the 4:3 resolution for drawings, unless I'm making a banner, in which 16:9 is better. The extra space isn't always required, as I will explain.
</p>
<h2>
 But what do I mean by scaling?
</h2>
<p>
 Perspective does play a part in scale, but that isn't what I'm referring to. You don't need to draw the body taking up the the whole page of the picture, depending on what you want to show in the picture. For example, a full body picture may not be needed if you want to emphasize a facial expression, or if you want to show a weapon being held, do you need to see the whole picture? If you leave too much negative/empty space around the object drawing, it may look out of place and distract people from what the actual focus is or may lessen what you want to make.
</p>
<p>
 The most common terms are:
</p>
<p>
 Headshot; best used for when you're trying to only focus on facial features, it usually stops around the neck.
</p>
<img alt="Close up of face" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/woman headshot2.png"/>
<p>
 Bust shot/half body; this is used to show the head down to about the waist, but some people stop by the waist instead.
</p>
<img alt="Mid shot of woman puttin on jacket." src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/shirt going on.png"/>
<p>
 Full body picture. Shows the whole body from head to feet.
</p>
<img alt="Josette far away." src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/josette.png"/>
<h2>
 Now that we have an idea about sizing, let's talk about space. More specifically, about what negative space can do to a picture.
</h2>
<p>
 Here's the roughly the same image: one is zoomed out, and one isn't. See the difference?
</p>
<img alt="Woman holding scythe closer" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/scythe1.png"/>
<img alt="Woman holding scythe farther" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/scythe2.png"/>
<p>
 We have the same space in the bottom left, but because I had to zoom out to show more of the scythe/body, it looks a bit more awkward now. Of course, we can draw something behind it/under it to fix this issue, but we're now doing more work for something that we didn't have to when showing less.
</p>
<p>
 You may think if you lower the resolution of your canvas, then it'd be easier to draw a certain size, but that's not true.
</p>
<p>
 Of course, on actual paper, you can get different-sized paper.
</p>
<h2>
 Drawing a rectangle to scale
</h2>
<p>
 If you have a hard time visualizing something to be smaller, you can instead draw a square/rectangle for the size you want. This can be helpful if you want to draw multiple smaller sketches on a bigger paper or if you want to help with sizing. If you remember, back to my first tutorial, scaling properly is key, and within the rectangle, you can add lines to scale the figure.
</p>
<img alt="Rectangle to scale" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/rectangle.png"/>
<img alt="picture of healer in rectangle" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/dr3 healer.png"/>
<img alt="Removing the rectangle" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/dr3 healer2.png"/>
<audio controls="">
 <source src="../audio/Les Filles Balancent.flac"/>
</audio>
<h2>
 Now that we have an understanding, of different picture scaling, and how to determine the sizes, let's continue.
</h2>
<p>
 If you want to draw something more complex, not just a picture with the characters facing forward like I showed you how to do in the previous tutorial. The first step is you'll have to visualize things around them. This is to say, background, what pose they'll be doing, if you're doing color, how the sun will cast a shadow.
</p>
<p>
 If the focus isn't on the character for the drawing, the character could be drawn smaller compared to what you want to emphasize or the other way around if needed.
</p>
<img alt="Close up of woman crying, holding person" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/cardboard.png"/>
<img alt="Mid shot of person playing music" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/playing flute.png"/>
<img alt="Woman on bed" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/woman sitting.png"/>
<p>
 I hope by giving a few other pictures at different shots and angles, you can see how moving the camera closer/farther or with things around them gives depths without needing shading.
</p>
<h2>
 Let's make a full picture with these concepts in mind.
</h2>
<p>
 This won't go into great detail like my last tutorial did, as the images above and the text should give enough details/ideas on the topics discussed. However, I'll still show off a bit of a WiP timelapse thing to give an idea of how I draw things and the different phases of what I want to focus on.
</p>
<img alt="Showing base image" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/first timelapse.png"/>
<p>
 I started with a rectangle to where I wanted the focus to be on and started to draw from there.
</p>
<img alt="Expanding on it" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/second timelapse.png"/>
<p>
 Expanded the roof, and made the space for the text. Now that I have the base for how I want things to go, we can start with the rest.
</p>
<img alt="Adding a person" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/third timelapse.png"/>
<p>
 Added a person and window. Now that all of that is done, I have to decide what I want the background to be, and what to have inside the building.
</p>
<img alt="Added background and text" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/fourth timelapse.png"/>
<p>
 Added the text, will move it out of the way of the docks. With all of this completed, I'll draw over it with a new layer.
</p>
<img alt="Cleaned up line art" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/fifth timelapse.png"/>
<p>
 Finished up the rest of the background, and I added clothes to the person. Now that all our line art is done, we can start coloring.
</p>
<img alt="Added color" src="https://www.radiant-ink.com/pics/tut/banner.png"/>
<p>
 I won't be showing the coloring process, as that's not what the tutorial is for, but the next tutorial will be about coloring. So I'll skip ahead to the finished picture. I'll be adding the text in the post for the front page.
</p>
<!-- Footer Section -->
<div class="footer">
 <a href="tuthome.html">
  Back to Tutorial Home
 </a>
</div>
]]>
